docs.lead_paragraph: A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about entrepreneurs working to make the Web available in more languages misidentified the person shown. He is Prasad Bhaarat Ram, an executive at Google India — not Ram Prakash Hanumanthappa, an engineer who developed software to type in 10 South Asian languages.

docs.lead_paragraph: Yahoo's Tough Year May Not Be Over It's no secret that 2008 was a tough year for Yahoo. There were the failed merger negotiations with Microsoft and the failed advertising partnership with Google. For many employees, much of the pain came from two rounds of layoffs, seemingly endless rounds of reorganizations and a sense that they were riding on a rudderless ship.

docs.snippet: The Chinese government broadened its effort to limit pornography on the Internet by criticizing 19 Internet companies on Monday, including the two market leaders in China, Google and Baidu. A statement on a government-run news site said that the c...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Chinese government broadened its effort to limit pornography on the Internet by criticizing 19 Internet companies on Monday, including the two market leaders in China, Google and Baidu. A statement on a government-run news site said that the companies had failed to do enough to stop the spread of pornography and that government agencies would work ''to purify the Internet's cultural environment and protect the healthy development of minors.''

headline.main: China: Crackdown On Pornography

docs.snippet: Google Trends, a service that shows the relative popularity of search terms, falls victim to stunt that shows a plane flying into two towers as a "Hot Trend."...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google Trends, a service that shows the relative popularity of search terms, fell victim to what appeared to be an ugly stunt on Tuesday: a sketch of an airplane flying into two towers appeared as its second most popular item under Hot Trends, its list of the fastest-rising searches at any given moment. TechCrunch and Search Engine Land both grabbed screen shots of the Google Trends page before the offending query receded in popularity later in the day.

headline.main: Google Trends Falls Victim to Disturbing Stunt

docs.abstract: Google Trends, a service that shows the relative popularity of search terms, falls victim to stunt that shows a plane flying into two towers as a "Hot Trend."

Second, its technology is believed to be better at matching ads to queries. And third, it has more advertisers. A lot more.

headline.main: Google: 1 Million Advertisers in 2007, More Now

docs.snippet: Available for noncommercial research license from The Linguistic Data Consortium (LDC), the corpus spans 20 years of the New York Times between 1987 and 2007 (that's 7,475 issues, to be exact). This collection includes the text of 1.8 million arti...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ah, January! It's that special time of year when marketers manipulate our resolution-shackled psyches to sell us all sorts of diet pills and exercise schemes. But if you're a researcher in computational linguistics, natural language processing or machine learning, the last thing you want to do is slim down. As Google's example has consistently shown, more data usually beats better algorithms, and if you're a researcher looking for a new motherlode of high-quality textual data - who also has a love of The New York Times's writerly chops - where better to start than The New York Times Annotated Corpus?

headline.main: Fatten Up Your Corpus

docs.abstract: Available for noncommercial research license from The Linguistic Data Consortium (LDC), the corpus spans 20 years of the New York Times between 1987 and 2007 (that's 7,475 issues, to be exact). This collection includes the text of 1.8 million articles written at The Times. Of these, more than 1.5 million have been manually annotated by The New York Times Index with distinct tags for people, places, topics and organizations drawn from a controlled vocabulary. A further 650,000 articles also include summaries written by indexers from the New York Times Index. The corpus is provided as a collection of XML documents in the News Industry Text Format and includes open source Java tools for parsing documents into memory resident objects.

docs.snippet: A Gutenberg Bible is enclosed in a glass case at the Morgan Library and Museum. (Jeff Zelevansky/Reuters) Google isn’t the only organization taking steps to make important works of literature available online. The Morgan Library & Museum in New ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google isn’t the only organization taking steps to make important works of literature available online. The Morgan Library & Museum in New York has invited technicians and scholars to create a digital facsimile of one of its Gutenberg Bibles, the library has announced. The Morgan has three copies of the work, printed in Mainz, Germany around 1455 and considered to be the first significant printed book in the West. The project is a result of a collaboration between the library and the Humanities Media Interface Project of Keio University in Tokyo. Images of all 1,026 pages of the bible will be on the library’s Web site. This is the latest effort by the library to expand its audience on the Web; It has already created digital copies of Book 1 of “Paradise Lost” as well as the delicate illustrations by Jean de Brunhoff from its recent exhibition “Drawing Babar: Early Drafts and Watercolors.” And it has begun to digitize the 183 tapes in the Paris Review archive, part of the Morgan’s permanent collection, including interviews with James Baldwin, Doris Lessing and Eudora Welty.

headline.main: Morgan Library to Digitize Gutenberg Bible

docs.abstract: A Gutenberg Bible is enclosed in a glass case at the Morgan Library and Museum. docs.snippet: Google has teamed up with the city to create an interactive visitors center with an online mapping site....
docs.lead_paragraph: Google's technological expertise helped turn New York City's main visitor center from a place to collect brochures into an interactive hub for planning a day - or a week - in the city. But the related Web site -- NYCGo -- proved so popular that it crashed almost as soon as it was unveiled and continued to operate slowly through Wednesday afternoon. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other city officials showed off the Official NYC Information Center, at 810 Seventh Avenue and West 53rd Street in Midtown, on Wednesday morning. At a cost of $1.8 million in private financing, the center was outfitted with video tabletop touch-screens equipped with Google Maps that allow users to assemble itineraries.

headline.main: Center Puts Google Maps at Tourists' Fingertips

docs.abstract: Google has teamed up with the city to create an interactive visitors center with an online mapping site.

docs.snippet: Internet | Did someone say digital democracy? Au contraire, Nicholas Carr writes. In a "blink of history's eye," he says, (1) a single medium, the Web, dominates the supply of information, (2) a single search engine, Google, dominates navigation o...
docs.lead_paragraph: Internet | Did someone say digital democracy? Au contraire, Nicholas Carr writes. In a "blink of history's eye," he says, (1) a single medium, the Web, dominates the supply of information, (2) a single search engine, Google, dominates navigation of that medium, and (3) a single information source, Wikipedia, dominates the Google search results. Behold the Web, once "radically heterogeneous," now "radically homogeneous." [Britannica]

headline.main: The New Information Big 3

[Britannica]

docs.snippet: CROSS--Seth, formerly of Southampton and New York City and lately of Larchmont, NY died of complications from lung cancer on January 5, at Sound Shore Medical Center in New Rochelle. He was 79 years old. Seth traveled the world while working as a ...
docs.lead_paragraph: CROSS--Seth, formerly of Southampton and New York City and lately of Larchmont, NY died of complications from lung cancer on January 5, at Sound Shore Medical Center in New Rochelle. He was 79 years old. Seth traveled the world while working as a Director of the Polychrome Corporation in Yonkers. A gourmet cook, crossword puzzle expert and everyone's answer to Google, Seth will be missed by his cadre of friends and particularly his cousins, Maureen Katz and Arlene Kandel. A memorial service will be held in April.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROSS, SETH

headline.main: Adieu, Google Notebook

docs.abstract: Google's useful Notebook application has been discontinued for new users, but other cloud-computing services remain.

docs.snippet: A five-year-old online prank that mocked former President George W. Bush pointed its snarkiness at President Obama last week as he was sworn in as president.     If you searched ''failure,'' on Google, or ''miserable failure'' on Yahoo's or Micros...
docs.lead_paragraph: A five-year-old online prank that mocked former President George W. Bush pointed its snarkiness at President Obama last week as he was sworn in as president. If you searched ''failure,'' on Google, or ''miserable failure'' on Yahoo's or Microsoft's search engines on Friday, the top result you were likely to get was a link to the biography of President Obama on the official Whitehouse.gov Web site. Before the inauguration, those searches linked to President Bush's biography on the site.

headline.main: A Joke on Bush Played on Obama
